body:
If you have manual port mapping setup, you can switch off upnp all together from the settings.
Also, it might start failing if you changed your device ID I think.
Is there an actual more useful error message, or a response dump?

@nbonacchi We'll need to see the underlying SOAP requests and responses to answer your questions. Enabling the debugging of UPnP discovery with the STTRACE environment variable should log detailed information about the SOAP requests to `stdout`, so if you copy the complete raw output of `./syncthing.x64 STTRACE=upnp` into a pastebin (or similar) and provide the link, we should be able to help you.

Did the device ID of the device which is asking for the UPnP mapping?

We use a random sequence of ports which is derived from the device ID.
When we ask UPnP device for a mapping, we ask for it under a name "syncthing", and always end up asking for the same port under the same name, which is fine.

As the device ID changes, the random sequence of ports we ask for changes as well, but we keep asking for it under the name "syncthing", so my router actually refuses to give out a different port under the same name, which could be your issue if the answer to my question is yes.

In that case, you might need to clean up UPnP mappings on the routers configuration page.
If your answer is No, then I guess you should follow @cqcallaw instructions.

The answer is yes! Actually I tried to create a UPnP mapping with the name syncthing manually and my router complained I ended up creating a syncthingSOMETHINGSOMETHING one.
My router also doesn't seem to like to overwrite previously existing mappings, you explicitly have to delete them, I guess, if I can fing that weird page with all the mappings listed. 
I understand now, thank you very much, the world makes sense again!! I'll clean things up in the router (if I can find the damn settings page again, I swear router interfaces are illogical on purpose) test this and let you know!

Thanks!

rename.to: UPnP mappings should use a unique name

body: Maybe we should create the mapping as syncthing-$deviceID or something, in case there are multiple instances...
Yes, I was thinking about first N characters like the log does.

Just an update...
Both cleaning up the UPnP mappings as turning the service off worked as expected!
I think its a great idea to do the mapping as syncthing-$deviceID the first 6 chars maybe?
On a related note: Could a user decide his own device ID? What's the rationale for making it random?
The reason I ask is because I had to reinstall syncthing because of a crash in a very old and with a lot of bad memory sector box and had to manually change the config.xml in all my machines to reflect the new name. Wouldn't it be easier to allow people to reuse a previously generated ID?

Thank you again for your help!
If I could come up with my own id I could impersonate you knowing your id.

If I could figure out your ID I would use it too :P 
It's not obvious that user chosen ID's are more easy to figure out than generated ones, however, I'm not advocating for that.
I'm talking about having a generated ID, exactly as now, with the possibility of using another (previously) generated ID in order to maintain the device's identity and connections, folders, etc.
make a backup of your certificates and you should get the same because it is generated from that if I remember correctly.

It just doesn't work that way. Read up on private/public key crypto. The ID is a hash of a private key which is 3072 characters long. The likelyness of you generating a random string which hashed would result in "my laptop" is very unlikely.

If we were to drop the idea of using private/public key crypto for the sake of using "my laptop", then anyone could impersonate anyone. You already have display names for devices for the purpose.

You have the posibility to save the ID, just back up the certificate files from the config directory.

issue.title: UPnP Port Mapping fails on Linux

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
With 0.10.13 syncthing started throwing UPnP Port Mapping errors.

Only usable output I can get is from STDOUT/STDERR at starting the daemon:

> [SFRDG] 00:53:54 INFO: Starting UPnP discovery...
> [SFRDG] 00:53:57 INFO: Invalid IGD response: invalid device UUID pnp-InternetGatewayDevice-1_0-cc354034bcdb (continuing anyway)
> [SFRDG] 00:54:00 INFO: UPnP discovery complete (found 1 device).
> [SFRDG] 00:54:00 WARNING: Failed to create UPnP port mapping

This problem didn't exist with syncthing 0.10.11 (was updated through syncthing-gtk from .11-->.13).

System is Linux Mint 17.1 x86_64 running the appropriate "amd64" Linux binary, but it also happens on my main openSUSE 13.2 x86_64 system (same error as aboe).

The Windows version doesn't seem to be affected as there was no such error after updating from .11 --> .12 --> .13.

Also, this is the first time I see that "Invalid IGD response" message.

If there's anything I can do to further try and debug the problem feel free what info I can provide you.
